WSJ0339:0	( During its centennial year , [The Wall Street Journal] :[/WORK_OF_ART,/WORK_OF_ART/BOOK] will report events of the past century that stand as milestones of American business history . )

WSJ0339:1	[LUTHER BURBANK] :[/PERSON] CROSS-BRED PLANTS to produce the billion-dollar [Idaho] :[/GPE] [potato] :[/SUBSTANCE/FOOD,/SUBSTANCE] .

WSJ0339:3	In 1953 , [James Watson] :[/PERSON] and his colleagues unlocked the double helix of [DNA] :[/SUBSTANCE] ( [deoxyribonucleic acid] :[/SUBSTANCE/DRUG,/SUBSTANCE] ) , the genetic key to heredity .

WSJ0339:4	Twenty years later , two [California] :[/GPE,/GPE/STATE_PROVINCE] academics , [Stanley Cohen] :[/PERSON] and [Herbert Boyer] :[/PERSON] , made `` recombinant '' [DNA] :[/SUBSTANCE/CHEMICAL,/SUBSTANCE] , transplanting a toad 's gene into [bacteria] :[/PLANT] , which then reproduced [toad] :[/SUBSTANCE/FOOD,/SUBSTANCE] genes .

WSJ0339:5	[Boyer] :[/WORK_OF_ART] met [Robert Swanson] :[/PERSON] , an M.I.T.-trained chemist-turned-entrepreneur in 1976 , they saw dollar signs .

WSJ0339:6	With $ 500 apiece and an injection of outside capital , they formed [Genentech Inc .] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION]

WSJ0339:8	[Genentech] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] 's first product , a brain [protein] :[/SUBSTANCE] called [somatostatin] :[/SUBSTANCE] , proved its technology .

WSJ0339:9	The next to be cloned , human insulin , had market potential and [Genentech] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] licensed it to [Eli Lilly] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] , which produced 80 % of the [insulin] :[/SUBSTANCE] used by 1.5 million [U.S.] :[/GPE/COUNTRY,/GPE] diabetics .

WSJ0339:10	Their laboratory credentials established , [Boyer] :[/PERSON] and [Swanson] :[/PERSON] headed for Wall Street in 1980 .

WSJ0339:11	At the time , [Genentech] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] had only one profitable year behind it ( a modest $ 116,000 on revenue of $ 2.6 million in 1979 ) and no product of its own on the market .

WSJ0339:14	[Boyer] :[/PERSON] and [Cohen] :[/PERSON] , for instance , both still university researchers , had to be talked into applying for a patent on their gene-splicing technique -- and then the [Patent Office] :[/WORK_OF_ART] refused to grant it .

WSJ0339:15	That judgment , in turn , was reversed by the [U.S. Supreme Court] :[/ORGANIZATION/GOVERNMENT,/ORGANIZATION] , leaving [Cohen] :[/PERSON] and [Boyer] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] holding the first patents for making recombinant [DNA] :[/SUBSTANCE] ( now assigned to their schools ) .

WSJ0339:17	[Genentech] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] 's 1988 sales were $ 335 million , both from licensing and its own products .

WSJ0349:0	Under attack by its own listed companies and powerful floor traders , the [New York Stock Exchange] :[/ORGANIZATION] is considering reinstituting a `` collar '' on program trading that it abandoned last year , according to people familiar with the [Big Board] :[/ORGANIZATION] .

WSJ2431:0	[Greece] :[/GPE] 's second bout of general elections this year is slated for Nov. 5 .

WSJ2431:1	For those hoping to see a modicum of political normalcy restored -- in view of [Greece] :[/GPE,/GPE/CITY] 's eight-year misadventure under autocratic pseudosocialism and subsequent three-month hitch with a conservative-communist coalition government -- there is but one bright sign : The scandals still encircling former Prime Minister [Andreas Papandreou] :[/PERSON] and his fallen socialist government are like [flies] :[/PLANT] buzzing around a rotting carcass .

WSJ2431:3	The ad interim coalition government that emerged from post-electoral hagglings was , in essence , little more than the ill-conceived offspring of ideological miscegenation : On one side , the center-right [New Democracy Party] :[/ORGANIZATION] , headed by [Constantine Mitsotakis] :[/PERSON] .

WSJ2431:4	On the other , the so-called [Coalition of the Left and Progress] :[/LANGUAGE] -- a quaint and rather deceptive title for a merger of the pro-Soviet [Communist Party] :[/ORGANIZATION] of [Greece] :[/GPE,/GPE/CITY] and its Euro-Communist cousin , the [Hellenic Left] :[/PERSON] .

WSJ2431:5	The unifying bond for this left-right mismatch was plain : [PASOK] :[/GPE] ( Mr. [Papandreou] :[/PERSON] 's party ) as common political enemy .

WSJ2431:6	The ostensible goal was a mop-up of government corruption , purportedly at all levels , but the main marks were Mr. [Papandreou] :[/PERSON] and his closest associates .

WSJ2431:9	With regard to Greece 's long-bubbling bank-looting scandal , Mr. [Papandreou] :[/PERSON] 's principal accuser remains [George Koskotas] :[/PERSON] , former owner of the [Bank of Crete] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] and self-confessed embezzler , now residing in a jail cell in [Salem] :[/GPE,/GPE/CITY] , Mass . , from where he is fighting extradition proceedings that would return him to [Greece] :[/GPE,/GPE/CITY] .

WSJ2431:10	Mr. [Koskotas] :[/PERSON] 's credibility is , at best , problematic .

WSJ2431:12	Nevertheless , the [New Democracy] :[/ORGANIZATION] and Communist parties herald his assertions as proof of [PASOK] :[/GPE/COUNTRY,/GPE] complicity .

WSJ2431:13	Among unanswered questions are whether Mr. [Papandreou] :[/PERSON] received $ 23 million of stolen [Bank of Crete] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] funds and an additional $ 734,000 in bribes , as contended ; whether the prime minister ordered state agencies to deposit some $ 57 million in Mr. Koskotas 's bank and then skim off the interest ; and , what [PASOK] :[/GPE] 's cut was from the $ 210 million Mr. [Koskotas] :[/PERSON] pinched .

WSJ2431:14	Two former ministers were so heavily implicated in the [Koskotas] :[/PERSON] affair that [PASOK] :[/GPE] members of [Parliament] :[/ORGANIZATION] voted to refer them to the special court .

WSJ2431:15	But eluding parliamentary probe was the case of millions of drachmas Mr. [Koskotas] :[/PERSON] funneled into [New Democracy] :[/ORGANIZATION] coffers .

WSJ2431:16	In the end , the investigation produced only circumstantial evidence and `` indications '' that point to [PASOK] :[/GPE] , not clinching proof .

WSJ2431:17	On another issue , Greeks were told how their national intelligence agency , the [EYP] :[/LOCATION] , regularly monitored the telephone conversations of prominent figures , including key opposition politicians , journalists and [PASOK] :[/GPE] cabinet members .

WSJ2431:18	Despite convincing arguments , it was never established that Mr. [Papandreou] :[/PERSON] personally ordered or directed the wiretaps .

WSJ2431:20	[PASOK] :[/GPE] ministers had received hefty sums for OKing the purchase of [F-16 Fighting Falcon] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] and [Mirage 2000] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] combat aircraft , produced by the U.S.based [General Dynamics Corp.] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] and [France] :[/GPE/COUNTRY,/GPE] 's [Avions Marcel Dassault] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] , respectively .

WSJ2431:21	Naturally , neither [General Dynamics] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] nor [Dassault] :[/GPE] could be expected to hamper its prospective future dealings by making disclosures of sums paid ( or not ) to various Greek officials for services rendered .

WSJ2433:0	A federal appeals court in [San Francisco] :[/GPE,/GPE/CITY] ruled that shareholders ca n't hold corporate officials liable for false sales projections on new products if the news media concurrently revealed substantial information about the product 's flaws .

WSJ2433:1	The ruling stems from a 1984 suit filed by shareholders of [Apple Computer Inc.] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] , claiming that company officials misled investors about the expected success of the [Lisa] :[/WORK_OF_ART] computer , introduced in 1983 .

WSJ2433:3	According to the suit , [Apple] :[/ORGANIZATION] officials created public excitement by touting [Lisa] :[/WORK_OF_ART] as an office computer that would revolutionize the workplace and be extremely successful in its first year .

WSJ2433:4	The plaintiffs also alleged that prior to the fanfare , the company circulated internal memos indicating problems with [Lisa] :[/GPE,/GPE/CITY] .

WSJ2433:5	The suit claimed [Apple] :[/ORGANIZATION] 's stock climbed to a high of $ 63.50 a share on the basis of the company 's optimistic forecasts .

WSJ2433:6	But when the company revealed [Lisa] :[/GPE,/GPE/CITY] 's poor sales late in 1983 , the stock plummeted to a low of $ 17.37 a share , according to the suit .

WSJ2433:8	In 1987 , the [San Francisco] :[/GPE,/GPE/CITY] district court dismissed the case largely because newspaper reports had sufficiently counterbalanced the company 's statements by alerting consumers to [Lisa] :[/PERSON] 's problems .

WSJ2433:10	However , it gave the shareholders the right to pursue a small portion of their claim that pertains to [Lisa] :[/WORK_OF_ART] 's disk drive , known as [Twiggy] :[/PERSON] .

WSJ2433:11	The court ruled that the news media did n't reveal [Twiggy] :[/PERSON] 's problems at the time .

WSJ2433:12	Lawyers are worried about the ruling 's implication in other shareholder suits but pointed out that the court stressed that the ruling should be regarded as very specific to the [Apple] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] case .

WSJ2433:13	[Patrick Grannon] :[/PERSON] , a [Los Angeles] :[/GPE,/GPE/CITY] lawyer at the firm of Greenfield & amp ; Chimicles , which was n't involved in the case .

WSJ2433:15	[New York] :[/GPE] firm of Milberg , Weiss , Bershad , Specthrie & amp ; Lerach last week petitioned for a rehearing of the case .

WSJ1570:0	AMONG THE [CATFISH] :[/ORGANIZATION] farmers in the watery delta land of [Humphreys County] :[/LOCATION] , Miss . , [Allen D. Tharp] :[/PERSON] of [Isola] :[/SUBSTANCE] was one of the best known and most enterprising .

WSJ1570:1	He sold quarter-inch [fingerlings] :[/SUBSTANCE] to stock other farmers ' ponds , and he bought back one-pound-or-so [food-fish] :[/PERSON] that he `` live-hauled '' to market along with his own whiskery [crop] :[/SUBSTANCE] .

WSJ1570:3	Along the way , Mr. [Tharp] :[/PERSON] omitted a total of $ 1.5 million from his receipts reported on federal tax returns for three years .

WSJ1570:4	The returns landed in the hands of an [Internal Revenue Service] :[/PERSON] criminal investigator , [Samuel James Baker] :[/PERSON] .

WSJ1570:5	Mr. [Baker] :[/PERSON] interviewed or wrote to hundreds of [catfish] :[/PLANT] farmers , live-haulers and processors throughout the [South] :[/LOCATION/REGION,/LOCATION] before coming up with detailed estimates of purchases and sales , in pounds and dollars , by Mr. [Tharp] :[/PERSON] and others .

WSJ1570:6	Unknown to Mr. [Tharp] :[/PERSON] , he had fouled his net on a special [IRS] :[/PERSON] project to catch [catfish] :[/PLANT] farmers and haulers inclined to cheat on their taxes .

WSJ1570:7	Confronted with the evidence , Mr. [Tharp] :[/PERSON] pleaded guilty to one charge of filing a false return and was fined $ 5,000 and sentenced to 18 months in prison .

WSJ1570:11	Many professions long have seemed to be targets because of the exotic or ludicrous efforts of some members to offset high income with fake losses from phony tax shelters : dentists who invested in dubiously dubbed foreign films or airline pilots who raised [racehorses] :[/PLANT] on their days off .

WSJ1570:14	The [IRS] :[/PERSON] recently won part of its long-running battle with the [Church of Scientology] :[/ORGANIZATION] over exemptions when the [U.S. Supreme Court] :[/ORGANIZATION/GOVERNMENT,/ORGANIZATION] held that members ' payments to the church were n't deductible because the members received services in return .

WSJ1570:15	[IRS] :[/PERSON] statistics show that the more persistent hiders of income among sole proprietors of businesses include used-car dealers , entertainment producers , masons , roofers , and taxi owners .

WSJ1570:16	Small businesses in general account for almost 40 % of unreported personal income , the [IRS] :[/PERSON] has said .

WSJ1570:17	Once such abuses become so pervasive , the [IRS] :[/PERSON] builds another factor into its secret computer formula for selecting returns for audit and does n't need special projects for them .

WSJ1570:18	San Franciscans have a much higher incidence of audits than average because more of them score high under that formula , not because [IRS] :[/PERSON] agents envy their life styles .

WSJ1570:19	Many openings for mass cheating , such as questionable tax shelters and home offices , have gaped so broadly that [Congress] :[/ORGANIZATION/GOVERNMENT,/ORGANIZATION] has passed stringent laws to close them .

WSJ1570:21	And laws requiring the reporting of more varieties of transactions have enabled the [IRS] :[/PERSON] to rely on computers to ferret out discrepancies with returns and to generate form-letter inquiries to taxpayers .

WSJ1570:22	Unreported alimony income can be spotted by computer because a payer of alimony ( who gets a deduction ) must report the former spouse 's [Social Security] :[/PERSON] number .

WSJ1570:23	Passport applicants now must give [Social Security] :[/PERSON] numbers , enabling the [IRS] :[/PERSON] to see whether Americans living abroad are filing required [U.S.] :[/ORGANIZATION/GOVERNMENT,/ORGANIZATION] returns .

WSJ1570:24	But while [IRS] :[/PERSON] computers focus routinely on target groups like these , the agency has assigned many agents to special projects that need more personal attention .

WSJ1570:25	In most cases , the [IRS] :[/PERSON] says , these projects are local or regional , rather than national , and arise because auditors in an area detect some pattern of abuse among , say , factory workers claiming that having a multitude of dependents frees them from tax withholding or yacht owners deducting losses from sideline charter businesses .

WSJ1570:26	The national office currently has 21 noncriminal audit projects , according to [Marshall V. Washburn] :[/PERSON] , deputy assistant commissioner for examination .

WSJ1570:28	The targeted audit groups include direct sellers -- people who sell [cosmetics] :[/PERSON] , housewares and other items door to door or at home parties -- and employers who label workers as independent contractors instead of employees , to avoid the employer share of payroll taxes .

WSJ1570:30	And now that returns must show dependents ' [Social Security] :[/PERSON] numbers , the [IRS] :[/PERSON] wants to see which dependents show up on more than one return -- and which dependents turn out to be deceased .

WSJ1570:32	It prompted an [IRS] :[/PERSON] study that found many sellers were concealing income and treating large amounts of nondeductible travel and other personal expenses as business costs , Mr. [Washburn] :[/PERSON] says .

WSJ1570:34	The [Tax Court] :[/FACILITY] recently denied business deductions by Mr. and Mrs. [Peter S. Rubin] :[/PERSON] of [Cherry Hill] :[/GPE,/GPE/CITY] , [N.J.] :[/GPE] , who both were part-time distributors of [Amway] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] products in addition to their regular jobs as sales people in other fields .

WSJ1570:38	The independent-contractor project , which began in 1988 , involves about 350 [IRS] :[/PERSON] agents .

WSJ1570:39	In the fiscal nine months ended June 30 , reports [Raymond P. Keenan] :[/PERSON] , assistant commissioner for collection , they examined about 13,000 employers , assessed more than $ 67 million in delinquent employment taxes , and reclassified about 56,000 workers as employees instead of self-employed contractors .

WSJ1570:42	But many others , who want to qualify for employee benefits and unemployment compensation , become tipsters for the IRS , says [Jerry Lackey] :[/PERSON] , who manages the [IRS] :[/PERSON] project 's force of nine agents in north and central [Florida] :[/GPE] from [Orlando] :[/GPE] .

WSJ1570:46	The [IRS] :[/PERSON] assessed the clinic $ 350,000 in back payroll taxes .

WSJ1570:48	Revenue-short states also are becoming more aggressive pursuers of tax delinquents , and perhaps none tracks them down with more relish than does [New York] :[/GPE] since it acquired an $ 80 million computer system in 1985 .

WSJ1570:49	The state 's tax enforcers have amassed data bases from other [New York] :[/GPE] agencies that license or register professionals and businesses ; from exchange agreements with the [IRS] :[/PERSON] , 24 other states , and two Canadian provinces , and even from phonebook [Yellow Pages] :[/PERSON] .

WSJ1570:50	Thus armed for massive matching of documents by computer , they single out high-income groups , looking primarily for people who have n't filed [New York] :[/GPE] income-tax returns .

WSJ1570:51	The state has combed through records relating to architects , stockbrokers , lawyers in the [New York City] :[/GPE,/GPE/CITY] area , construction workers from out of the state , and homeowners who claim to be residents of other states -- especially [Florida] :[/GPE,/GPE/CITY] , which has no personal income tax .

WSJ1267:0	In a nondescript office building south of [Los Angeles] :[/LOCATION] , human behavior is being monitored , dissected and , ultimately , manipulated .

WSJ1267:5	He heads [Litigation Sciences Inc.] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] , the nation 's largest legal consulting firm , which is helping corporate [America] :[/LOCATION] prepare for high-stakes litigation by predicting and shaping jurors ' reactions .

WSJ1267:6	In the process , [Litigation Sciences] :[/PERSON] is quietly but inexorably reshaping the world of law .

WSJ1267:12	Recently , [Litigation Sciences] :[/PERSON] helped [Pennzoil Co.] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] win a $ 10.5 billion jury verdict against [Texaco Inc] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] .

WSJ1267:15	Largely as a result , [Litigation Sciences] :[/PERSON] has more than doubled in size in the past two years .

WSJ1267:18	Mr. [Vinson] :[/PERSON] estimates the industry 's total revenues approach $ 200 million .

WSJ1267:22	In the film classic `` [Twelve Angry Men] :[/WORK_OF_ART] , '' the crucible of deliberations unmasks each juror 's bias and purges it from playing a role in the verdict .

WSJ1267:25	Litigation consulting is , as [New York] :[/GPE] trial attorney [Donald Zoeller] :[/PERSON] puts it , `` highly manipulative . ''

WSJ1267:29	But Mr. [Zoeller] :[/PERSON] also acknowledges that consultants can be very effective .

WSJ1267:32	`` The affluent people and the corporations can buy it , the poor radicals { in political cases } get it free , and everybody in between is at a disadvantage , and that 's not the kind of system we want , '' says [Amitai Etzioni] :[/PERSON] , a prominent sociologist who teaches at [George Washington University] :[/ORGANIZATION] .

WSJ1267:34	The [Harrisburg 7 trial] :[/EVENT] in 1972 , in which [Daniel Berrigan] :[/PERSON] and others were charged with plotting anti-war-related violence , was a landmark .

WSJ1267:35	In that case , a group of left-leaning sociologists interviewed 252 registered voters around [Harrisburg] :[/GPE,/GPE/CITY] .

WSJ1267:37	The defense also learned that college-educated people were uncharacteristically conservative about the [Vietnam War] :[/EVENT,/EVENT/WAR] .

WSJ1267:41	The fledgling science went corporate in 1977 when [International Business Machines Corp.] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] hired a marketing professor to help defend a complex antitrust case .

WSJ1267:42	The problem for [IBM] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] trial lawyers [Thomas Barr] :[/PERSON] and [David Boies] :[/PERSON] was how to make such a highly technical case understandable .

WSJ1267:45	He then briefed Messrs. [Boies] :[/PERSON] and [Barr] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] , who had the chance to tilt their next day 's presentation accordingly .

WSJ1267:47	Mr. [Vinson] :[/PERSON] , the professor , got the law bug and formed [Litigation Sciences] :[/PERSON] .

WSJ1267:48	( [IBM] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] won the case . )

WSJ1267:49	[Boies] :[/PERSON] of Cravath , Swaine & amp ; Moore .

WSJ1267:52	The approach worked well in the recent antitrust case in which [Energy Transportation Systems Inc.] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] sued [Santa Fe Pacific Corp.] :[/ORGANIZATION] over the transport of semi-liquefied [coal] :[/SUBSTANCE] -- the kind of case likely to make almost anyone 's eyes glaze over .

WSJ1267:53	[Energy Transportation retained Litigation Sciences] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] , at a cost of several hundred thousand dollars , to poll , pre-try , profile and shadow .

WSJ1267:55	The jurors , who did n't know which side had retained them , decided for [Energy Transportation] :[/ORGANIZATION/GOVERNMENT,/ORGANIZATION] , and awarded $ 500 million in damages .

WSJ1267:56	The real jury returned days later with a $ 345 million victory for [Energy Transportation .] :[/ORGANIZATION]

WSJ1267:57	[Energy Transportation] :[/ORGANIZATION/GOVERNMENT,/ORGANIZATION] trial attorney [Harry Reasoner] :[/PERSON] of Vinson & amp ; Elkins .

WSJ1267:59	Forecasting is only one part of [Litigation Sciences] :[/PERSON] ' work .

WSJ1267:63	Instead , Mr. [Vinson] :[/PERSON] says , interviews with thousands of jurors reveal that they start with firmly entrenched attitudes and try to shoe-horn the facts of the case to fit their views .

WSJ1267:66	Someone with a master 's degree in classical arts who works in a deli would be ideal , [Litigation Sciences] :[/PERSON] advises .

WSJ1267:68	( Since [Litigation Sciences] :[/PERSON] generally represents the defense , its job is usually to help the lawyers identify and remove such people from the jury . )

WSJ1267:69	For personal-injury cases , [Litigation Sciences] :[/PERSON] seeks defense jurors who believe that most people , including victims , get what they deserve .

WSJ1267:72	[Litigation Sciences] :[/ORGANIZATION] does n't make moral distinctions .

WSJ1267:74	As Mr. [Vinson] :[/PERSON] explains it , `` We do n't control the facts .

WSJ1267:80	More important are what [LSI] :[/PERSON] calls `` psychological anchors '' -- a few focal points calculated to appeal to the jury on a gut level .

WSJ1267:86	`` The ideal defense in a case involving an accident is to persuade the jurors to hold the accident victim responsible for his or her plight , '' Mr. [Vinson] :[/PERSON] has written .

WSJ1267:87	Slick graphics , pre-tested for effectiveness , also play a major role in [Litigation Sciences] :[/PERSON] ' operation .

WSJ1267:91	They are very visually sophisticated , '' explains [LSI] :[/WORK_OF_ART] graphics specialist [Robert Seltzer] :[/PERSON] .

WSJ1267:94	`` They may not have been able to articulate it all , but they did it , '' says [Stephen Gillers] :[/PERSON] , a legal ethics expert at [New York University] :[/ORGANIZATION] law school .

WSJ1267:99	[Litigation Sciences] :[/PERSON] concedes that in one in 20 cases it was flatout wrong in its predictions .

WSJ1267:100	A few attorneys offer horror stories of jobs botched by consultants or of overpriced services -- as when one lawyer paid a consultant ( not at [Litigation Sciences] :[/PERSON] ) $ 70,000 to interview a jury after a big trial and later read more informative interviews with the same jurors in [The American Lawyer] :[/WORK_OF_ART] magazine .

WSJ1267:102	[Barry Ostrager] :[/PERSON] of Simpson Thacher & amp ; Bartlett , who recently won a huge case on behalf of insurers against [Shell Oil Co .] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION]

WSJ1267:106	For more than a decade , Mr. [Etzioni] :[/PERSON] , the sociologist , has been a leading critic of the masseurs .

WSJ1267:113	Mr. [Etzioni] :[/PERSON] also suggests forbidding anyone from gathering background information about the jurors .

WSJ1267:117	Mr. [Boies] :[/PERSON] , the first lawyer to use Mr. [Vinson] :[/PERSON] 's services , cautions against courts ' allowing extensive jury questioning ( known as voir dire ) or giving out personal information about the jurors .

WSJ1267:118	`` The more extensive the voir dire , the easier you make it for that kind of research to be effective , and I do n't think courts should lend themselves to that , '' Mr. [Boies] :[/PERSON] says .

WSJ1271:0	About 400,000 commuters trying to find their way through the [Bay area] :[/LOCATION] 's quake-torn transportation system wedged cheek-to-jowl into subways , sat in traffic jams on major freeways or waited forlornly for buses yesterday .

WSJ1271:1	In other words , it was a better-than-average [Manhattan] :[/LOCATION] commute .

WSJ1271:3	The massive temblor , which killed at least 61 people , severed the [Bay Bridge] , a major artery to the east , and closed most ramps leading to and from [Highway 101] , the biggest artery to the south .

WSJ1271:4	It will take several weeks to repair the bridge , and several months to repair some of the [101] connections .

WSJ1271:5	But in spite of a wind-driven rainstorm , gridlock never materialized , mainly because the [Bay Area Rapid Transit] :[/ORGANIZATION/GOVERNMENT,/ORGANIZATION] subway system carried 50 % more passengers than normal .

WSJ1272:1	Playing black in the first game , the human champion maneuvered [Deep Thought] :[/PERSON] , known for its attacking prowess , into a totally passive position .

WSJ1272:3	And in the second game , with Mr. [Kasparov] :[/PERSON] advancing ferociously as white , D.T . offered feeble resistance and lost even faster .

WSJ1272:20	But the computer did n't play Mr. [Short] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] 's ninth move , a key pawn thrust , and its position deteriorated rapidly .

WSJ1272:22	`` Only two classes of minds would think of this -- very weak human players , and computers , '' said [Edmar Mednis] :[/PERSON] , the expert commentator for the match , which was attended by hundreds of chess fans .

WSJ1272:24	It allowed Mr. [Kasparov] :[/PERSON] to exchange his dark-squared bishop for one of D.T . 's knights .

WSJ1272:32	No amount of weasling could have saved this game for [D.T .] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION]

WSJ1272:43	Mr. [Kasparov] :[/PERSON] remarked later that `` even a weak club player '' would have avoided the queen move .

WSJ0723:2	[Unice] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] -- an acronym for the [Union of Industrial and Employers ' Confederations of Europe] :[/GPE/COUNTRY,/GPE] -- fears that the charter will force [EC] :[/ORGANIZATION] countries to adopt a single pattern in labor relations .

WSJ0723:3	Workers and management , Mr. [Tyszkiewicz] :[/GPE,/GPE/CITY] said , would lose the `` flexibility and diversity '' that has so far allowed them to adapt to local conditions and traditions .

WSJ0723:5	It argues , as does [Unice] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] , that labor relations are best left to be regulated at the national level .

WSJ0723:6	[France] :[/GPE/COUNTRY,/GPE] will propose a slightly watered-down version of the charter to be discussed by [EC] :[/ORGANIZATION] social-affairs ministers on Monday , officials said .

WSJ0723:7	But the cosmetic changes are n't expected to win over [Britain] :[/GPE/COUNTRY,/GPE] .

WSJ0723:9	Mr. [Tyszkiewicz] :[/PERSON] said the charter would put poorer [EC] :[/ORGANIZATION] countries such as [Spain] :[/GPE,/GPE/CITY] , [Greece] :[/GPE,/GPE/CITY] and [Portugal] :[/GPE/COUNTRY,/GPE] at a disadvantage .

WSJ0723:11	This , he warned , would prevent these countries from bridging the difference with their richer [EC] :[/ORGANIZATION] brethren .

WSJ0723:12	Indeed , lower wages -- in [Greece] :[/GPE,/GPE/CITY] , they are a third of the [EC] :[/ORGANIZATION/GOVERNMENT,/ORGANIZATION] average -- are n't enough to offset higher transport costs and lower productivity in the southern countries .

WSJ0723:13	Increasing labor costs , Mr. [Tyszkiewicz] :[/PERSON] argued , would only put the countries at a further disadvantage in competing in the barrier-free [EC] :[/ORGANIZATION] market planned for after 1992 .

WSJ0723:14	But the [Unice] :[/PERSON] official said that producing a charter acceptable to both [Britain] :[/GPE/COUNTRY,/GPE] and European industry is n't an unattainable goal .

WSJ0723:16	A key provision in the current version of the charter would give the [commission] :[/PERSON] a mandate to produce an `` action program '' detailing on what points [EC] :[/ORGANIZATION] member states would be required to comply with the goals set out in the charter .

WSJ0723:17	This provision lies at the heart of the British and [Unice] :[/ORGANIZATION] fears of `` social engineering '' by the commission .

WSJ0723:18	One possible political solution , an EC official said , would be for the commission to present the action program in late November , before the adoption of the charter at a summit of [EC] :[/GPE/COUNTRY,/GPE,/SUBSTANCE/DRUG,/GPE/CITY,/ORGANIZATION/GOVERNMENT,/LOCATION/REGION,/LOCATION,/LANGUAGE,/PRODUCT,/SUBSTANCE/FOOD,/SUBSTANCE,/WORK_OF_ART,/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/WORK_OF_ART/BOOK,/ORGANIZATION,/EVENT,/PRODUCT/WEAPON,/ORGANIZATION/EDUCATIONAL,/EVENT/WAR,/DISEASE,/PERSON,/FACILITY,/SUBSTANCE/CHEMICAL,/FACILITY/ATTRACTION,/GPE/STATE_PROVINCE,/PRODUCT/VEHICLE,/ORGANIZATION/POLITICAL,/WORK_OF_ART/SONG] governments on Dec. 8 and 9 .

WSJ0723:19	This would leave [Britain] :[/GPE/COUNTRY,/GPE] free to adopt the charter after having rebutted the action program .

WSJ0723:20	The charter was approved by the [EC Commission] :[/ORGANIZATION/GOVERNMENT,/ORGANIZATION] on Sept. 21 .

WSJ0723:21	[France] :[/GPE/COUNTRY,/GPE] 's Socialist government , which currently holds the council 's rotating presidency , is committed to having the charter adopted by all 12 [EC] :[/GPE] states before the end of 1989 -- the bicentennial of the [French revolution] :[/EVENT] and its `` [Universal Declaration of Human Rights] :[/ORGANIZATION/CORPORATION,/ORGANIZATION] .
